name: warming
content:
warming

noun
 
 
/ˈwɔːmɪŋ/
 
/ˈwɔːrmɪŋ/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. ​the process of making something, or of becoming, warm or warmer
    • atmospheric warming
    • the seasonal warming of the Pacific
    see also global warming
See warming in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee warming in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: warming

name: warming
content:
warming

adjective
 
/ˈwɔːmɪŋ/
 
/ˈwɔːrmɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. ​making something/somebody warmer
    • the warming rays of the sun
    • a warming drink
Check pronunciation: warming

name: warm
content:
warm

verb
 
 
/wɔːm/
 
/wɔːrm/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they warm
 
/wɔːm/
 
/wɔːrm/
he / she / it warms
 
/wɔːmz/
 
/wɔːrmz/
past simple warmed
 
/wɔːmd/
 
/wɔːrmd/
past participle warmed
 
/wɔːmd/
 
/wɔːrmd/
-ing form warming
 
/ˈwɔːmɪŋ/
 
/ˈwɔːrmɪŋ/
Idioms Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results

    make/become warm

  1. ​
     
     [transitive, intransitive] to make something/somebody warm or warmer; to become warm or warmer
    • warm something/somebody/yourself Come in and warm yourself by the fire.
    • The alcohol warmed and relaxed him.
    • warm something/somebody/yourself up I'll warm up some milk.
    • There is little doubt that the planet is warming.
    • warm up As the climate warms up, the ice caps will melt.
    • We soon warmed up in front of the fire.
    • warm through Return the bowl to the heat to warm through.
    • warm something through Poach until the fish is warmed through.
    Topics Cooking and eatingb1, Weatherb1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • properly
    • sufficiently
    • thoroughly
    • …
    See full entry
    2.

    become friendly

  2. ​[intransitive, transitive] warm (somebody/something) to become more friendly, loving, etc.; to make somebody feel or become more friendly, loving, etc.
    • His voice suddenly warmed.
    • The story warmed our hearts.
    3. see also global warming, house-warming
    Word OriginOld English wearm (adjective), werman, wearmian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German warm, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin formus ‘warm’ and Greek thermos ‘hot’.
Idioms
look/feel like death warmed up (British English)
(North American English like death warmed over)
  1. ​(informal) to look or feel very ill or tired
warm the cockles (of somebody’s heart)
  1. ​(British English) to make somebody feel happy or sympathetic
    • Doesn’t that story just warm the cockles of your heart?
Phrasal Verbs
  • warm down
  • warm to
  • warm towards
  • warm up
See warm in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee warm in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: warm
relatives: lovely and warm, cold, quiet, etc.

name: warming pan
content:
warming pan

noun
 
/ˈwɔːmɪŋ pæn/
 
/ˈwɔːrmɪŋ pæn/
jump to other results
  1. ​a metal container with a long handle that, in the past, was filled with hot coals and used to warm beds
See warming pan in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: heart-warming
content:
heart-warming

adjective
 
/ˈhɑːt wɔːmɪŋ/
 
/ˈhɑːrt wɔːrmɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. ​causing feelings of happiness and pleasure
    • a heart-warming story
    • It’s heart-warming to hear of the success you’ve had with the appeal.
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryHeart-warming is used with these nouns:
    • tale
    See full entry
Check pronunciation: heart-warming

name: house-warming
content:
house-warming

noun
 
/ˈhaʊs wɔːmɪŋ/
 
/ˈhaʊs wɔːrmɪŋ/
(also house-warming party)
jump to other results
  1. ​a party given by somebody who has just moved into a new home
    • a house-warming present/gift
    Topics Houses and homesc1
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryHouse-warming is used before these nouns:
    • party
    • present
    See full entry
Check pronunciation: house-warming

name: warming trend
content:
warming trend

noun
 
/ˈwɔːmɪŋ trend/
 
/ˈwɔːrmɪŋ trend/
(especially North American English)
jump to other results
  1. ​a period of time when the temperature increases in a particular region
    • There has been a strong warming trend over the past 30 years.
See warming trend in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: warming trend

name: global warming
content:
global warming

noun
 
/ˌɡləʊbl ˈwɔːmɪŋ/
 
/ˌɡləʊbl ˈwɔːrmɪŋ/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. ​the increase in temperature of the earth’s atmosphere that is caused by the increase of particular gases, especially carbon dioxide
    • a conference on global warming
    Collocations The environmentThe environmentEnvironmental damage
    • cause/​contribute to climate change/​global warming
    • produce pollution/​CO2/greenhouse (gas) emissions
    • damage/​destroy the environment/​a marine ecosystem/​the ozone layer/​coral reefs
    • degrade ecosystems/​habitats/​the environment
    • harm the environment/​wildlife/​marine life
    • threaten natural habitats/​coastal ecosystems/​a species with extinction
    • deplete natural resources/​the ozone layer
    • pollute rivers and lakes/​waterways/​the air/​the atmosphere/​the environment/​oceans
    • contaminate groundwater/​the soil/​food/​crops
    • log forests/​rainforests/​trees
    Protecting the environment
    • address/​combat/​tackle the threat/​effects/​impact of climate change
    • fight/​take action on/​reduce/​stop global warming
    • limit/​curb/​control air/​water/​atmospheric/​environmental pollution
    • cut/​reduce pollution/​greenhouse gas emissions
    • offset carbon/​CO2 emissions
    • reduce (the size of) your carbon footprint
    • achieve/​promote sustainable development
    • preserve/​conserve biodiversity/​natural resources
    • protect endangered species/​a coastal ecosystem
    • prevent/​stop soil erosion/​overfishing/​massive deforestation/​damage to ecosystems
    • raise awareness of environmental issues
    • save the planet/​the rainforests/​an endangered species
    Energy and resources
    • conserve/​save/​consume/​waste energy
    • manage/​exploit/​be rich in natural resources
    • dump/​dispose of hazardous/​toxic/​nuclear waste
    • dispose of/​throw away litter/(especially British English) rubbish/(especially North American English) garbage/(North American English) trash/​sewage
    • use/​be made from recycled/​recyclable/​biodegradable material
    • recycle bottles/​packaging/​paper/​plastic/​waste
    • promote/​encourage recycling/​sustainable development/​the use of renewable energy
    • develop/​invest in/​promote renewable energy
    • reduce your dependence/​reliance on fossil fuels
    • get/​obtain/​generate/​produce electricity from wind, solar and wave power/​renewable sources
    • build/​develop a (50-megawatt/​offshore) wind farm
    • install/​be fitted with/​be powered by solar panels
    compare climate change see also greenhouse effectTopics The environmentb1
See global warming in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee global warming in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
